Issues.Title: Add Code Coverage For ToolStrip
Issues.Body:
related https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/10453

## Proposed changes
- Add unit tests for ToolStrip to test its properties: Visible, Size, BackgroundImage, CausesValidation, ContextMenuStrip, CausesValidation, Cursor, ForeColor
- Add unit tests for ToolStrip to test its methods: Compare(), Show()
- Add unit tests for ToolStrip to test its events: DockChanged, BackColorChanged, BackgroundImageChanged, BackgroundImageLayoutChanged, BottomToolStripPanelVisible,CausesValidationChanged, ContextMenuStripChanged, CursorChanged
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/11464)

Issues.Title: NativeHost crash for debug version on .Net 8.0
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Version is .net8.0



### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes. It works fine for .Net 7.0 

### Issue description

NativeHost.exe crash for .net 8.0 debug version.  It works fine for release version on .net 8.0. It also works fine for other .net version
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/11794711/b8c6315f-40d7-4445-a47c-74b5d060c6a1)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Build NativeHost on release/8.0 branch with debug version.
2. Run it and you will get crash issue
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "NativeHost crash for debug version on .Net 8.0" (#11482)

Issues.Title: publish single file doesnt seem to work anymore
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

```
.NET SDK:
 Version:           8.0.300
 Commit:            326f6e68b2
 Workload version:  8.0.300-manifests.4e5ea2d8
 MSBuild version:   17.10.4+10fbfbf2e

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.22631
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\8.0.300\

.NET workloads installed:
There are no installed workloads to display.

Host:
  Version:      8.0.5
  Architecture: x64
  Commit:       087e15321b

.NET SDKs installed:
  8.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

.NET runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 8.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.25 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 7.0.14 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 8.0.0 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 8.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.25 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 7.0.14 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 8.0.0 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 8.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]

Other architectures found:
  x86   [C:\Program Files (x86)\dotnet]
    registered at [HKLM\SOFTWARE\dotnet\Setup\InstalledVersions\x86\InstallLocation]

Environment variables:
  Not set

global.json file:
  Not found
```

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

.NET 8.0.0 

Compiled at Jan 6, 2024 without issues.

### Issue description

When I try to compile a single file exe, it does not publish anything

In Visual Studio, Build -> Publish, Folder, then target runtime=win-x64, framework dependent, check on 'produce single file'. It will compile the Release build in `/bin/Release` with all DLLs separate from the executable but does not produce a publish folder no matter where I put it or if it exists or not. There's also no errors showing in the output log.

It used to produce a single EXE for all of my projects in `/bin/publish` folder. I have not changed them in months and the last time I compiled them, it created the EXEs just fine. I went to fix a bug in one project, tried to compile it and got this issue. Loaded another project from January 6 that hadn't been touched since and it had the same publishing issue. Created a brand new winforms project, didn't change a thing in the codebase itself, tried to publish that with the same settings and same issue.

Googling around doesn't seem to have any help, all other similar types of issues that I was able to find had some kind of error in the output. As far as I can tell, it compiles just fine, just doesn't actually pack the files.

The only change since last compile was updating VS Community 2022 to 17.10.1.

Running `dotnet publish -c Release -r win-x64 --self-contained false -p:PublishSingleFile=true -p:IncludeNativeLibrariesForSelfExtract=true` via command line does work strangely enough.

### Steps to reproduce

- Create new blank WinForms project.
- Go to build -> publish -> to folder
set configuration to 'release'
target framework to 'net8.0-windows'
deployment tools to 'framework dependent'
target runtime to 'win-x64'
target location doesn't matter, I left it as default 'bin\Release\net8.0-windows\publish\win-x64\'
check on 'produce single file'
- click publish. It will compile then show this in the output
```
Build started at 12:27 AM...
1>------ Build started: Project: WinFormsApp1, Configuration: Release Any CPU ------
1>WinFormsApp1 -> C:\Users\aland\Desktop\New folder\WinFormsApp1\bin\Release\net8.0-windows\WinFormsApp1.dll
========== Build: 1 succeeded, 0 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========
========== Build completed at 12:27 AM and took 01.390 seconds ==========
```
It will have the 'release' files under `\bin\Release\net8.0-windows` with all the separate DLLs, but no `publish\win-x64\` folder in there.

Issues.Title: Enable `png` based `ico` files and streams to be loaded into `Bitmap`
Issues.Body:
In PR #11375 we discovered that when converting `bmp` based `ico` resources to be `png` based, there was a failure when loading the icons as the `ToolboxBitmapAttribute` tries to create the resource as a `bitmap`. This errors out as `bitmap` uses different PInvokes from `Icon`, with `Icon` PInvokes supporting `png` for a few windows versions.

This would enable us to convert the `ico` files to be `png` based, saving a few megabytes in an AOT compiled app (#11370).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable `png` based `ico` files and streams to be loaded into `Bitmap`" (#11469)

Issues.Title: VisualStudio crashes when calling fileDialog.ShowDialog at DesignTime
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Edition - Windows 11 Enterprise
Version - 23H2
OS build - 22631.3593
Visual Studio version - 17.10.1


### .NET version

.Netcore 6 , 7, 8

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

No it doesn't work on previous netcore releases. 

### Issue description

I am attempting to initialize a `FileDialog` (either `SaveFileDialog` or `OpenFileDialog`) and call the `fileDialog.ShowDialog` method within a custom control's property setter. When I try to change the property value in the property window at **DesignTime**, Visual Studio crashes.

For your reference, I have attached a simple sample that replicates the issue.
Sample - [FileDialog_Crash.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/15518020/FileDialog_Crash.zip)


### Steps to reproduce

1.Drag and Drop the CustomControl from the toolbox.
2.Change the value of the NativeCheck property to true.

Expected Behavior : - FileDialog needs to be open.
Observed Behavior : - VS crashes

### Diagnostics

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "VisualStudio crashes when calling fileDialog.ShowDialog at DesignTime" (#11468)

Issues.Title: Drawing a line of thickness 1 issue
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

When I draw a line of thickness 1 using the Graphics.DrawLine method, then the length of the line becomes larger by 1.
If I draw a line with a thickness greater than 1 along the same coordinates, then its length will be correct.
Changing property Graphics.SmoothingMode to None does not affect the result.
Also, methods Graphics.DrawPolygon and Graphics.DrawPath have the same issue.
![](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/103027300/b470bbfe-89c8-4e12-847a-471c18419e21)



### Steps to reproduce

1. Run attached app: 
[DrawLineIssue.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/15500503/DrawLineIssue.zip)
2. Observe incorrect result.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Drawing a line of thickness 1 issue" (#11461)

Issues.Title: At 200% zoom data present in the "Custom accessible properties form" dialog is truncating and not visible: A11y_.NET CoreWinforms_Custom accessible properties form_Zoom
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

dotnet-sdk-9.0.100-preview.5.24258.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

### GitHub Tags:
#A11yMAS; #A11yTCS; #A11ySev2; #BM_.NET Core[Winforms]_Win32_May2024; #.NETCore; #WCAG1.4.4; #DesktopApp; #Win11; #FTP; #Zoom;

### Environment Details:
App name: .NET Core Winforms
Window Version: Win 11
OS Build: 22621.3085

### Prerequisites:
Display resolution: 1280*768
Scale-> Custom scaling 200%

### Repro Steps:

1. Launch the "Accessibility core app".
2. Main Form screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Accessible properties: Testings controls with custom accessible name, role and description" and hit ENTER key.
4. "Custom accessible properties form" screen would appear.
5. Do the resize resolution and observe that At 200% zoom data present in the "Custom accessible properties form" dialog is truncating and not visible.

### Actual Result:
At 200% zoom data present in the "Custom accessible properties form" dialog is truncating and not visible

### Expected Result:
At 200% zoom data present in the "Custom accessible properties form" dialog should be clearly visible.

### User Impact:
Low vision users will not be able to see the controls clearly and will not be getting information related to those.

### Attachment
![11458_A11y_ NET CoreWinforms_Custom accessible properties form_Zoom](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/90901519/1779ec02-b1b8-43e3-b092-f3b2aa07e238)

Issues.Title: At 200% zoom buttons present under 'Remaining_Controls_Testing' are not visible: A11y_.NET CoreWinforms_MainForm_Zoom
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

dotnet-sdk-9.0.100-preview.5.24258.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

### GitHub Tags:
#A11yMAS; #A11yTCS; #A11ySev1; #BM_.NET Core[Winforms]_Win32_May2024; #.NETCore; #WCAG1.4.4; #DesktopApp; #Win11; #FTP; #Zoom;

### Environment Details:
App name: .NET Core Winforms
Window Version: Win 11
OS Build: 22621.3085

### Prerequisites:

1. Display resolution: 1280*768
2. Scale-> Custom scaling 200%

### Repro Steps:

1. Launch the "Accessibility core app".
2. Main Form screen would appear.
3. Do the resize resolution and observe that At 200% zoom buttons present under 'Remaining_Controls_Testing' are not visible.

### Actual Result:
At 200% zoom buttons present under 'Remaining_Controls_Testing' are not visible.

**Similar issue is also observed in below scenario:
Issue 1: ToolStripContainer_Bottomtool bar**

1. Launch the "Accessibility core app".
2. Main Form screen would appear.
3. TAB to "MenuToolbars_Controls:Testing the controls under Menu Toolbars Tab" and hit ENTER key.
4. TAB to ToolStripContainer button and hit ENTER key.
5. TAB to "Button1" present at the botoom
6. Observe that at 200% zoom "Button1" present at the bottom is not visible.

**Issue2: Print_ Preference**

1. Launch the "Accessibility core app".
2. Main Form screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under Printing Tab" and hit ENTER key.
4. TAB to Print button and hit ENTER key.
5. TAB to More setting button and hit ENTER key.
6. "Printing Preference" Screen would appear.
7. Observe that at 200% "Advance", "ok" and "Cancel" buttons are not visible.

### Expected Result:
At 200% zoom buttons present under 'Remaining_Controls_Testing' should be clearly visible.

### User Impact:
Low vision users will not be able to see the controls clearly and will not be getting information related to those.

### Attachment
![11457_A11y_ NET CoreWinforms_MainForm_Zoom](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/90901519/edaa21b2-0caa-40bb-928b-b318682393f6)

Issue1: 
![11457_Issue 1_ Toolstripcontainer](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/90901519/e63fd28a-658e-4c69-970c-59d1bac30588)

Issue2: 
![11457_Issue2_ Print_ Preference](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/90901519/a75d2507-ddd0-4ecf-8fa8-09418ccdb1bd)
